description: From Middle English conserven, from Old French conserver, from Latin conservare (“to keep, preserve”), from com- (intensive prefix) + servo (“keep watch, maintain”). See also observe.

entries.meaning: Wilderness where human development is prohibited.
A jam or thick syrup made from fruit.
examples: I shall  […]  study broths, plasters, and conserves, till from a fine lady I become a notable woman.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A medicinal confection made of freshly gathered vegetable substances mixed with finely powdered refined sugar.

examples: water […] alwayes placed in the Conserve

verbs.description: conserve (third-person singular simple present conserves, present participle conserving, simple past and past participle conserved)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To save for later use, sometimes by the use of a preservative.
(transitive) To protect an environment, heritage, etc.
(physics, chemistry, intransitive) To remain unchanged during a process
